title: How to Clean Household Cleaning Tools

steps.headline: Run an empty cycle.
steps.description: Every few weeks add bleach in the soap box or a cup of vinegar and run on the highest temperature.

steps.headline: Clean dishwasher once a week.
steps.description: Clean your dishwasher by leaving it open to cool after you run it about once per week. That way all the steam can escape and it won’t build up on the racks in your dishwasher.

steps.headline: Remove grime once a month.
steps.description: Wipe down the bottom section of your dishwasher about once per month with paper towels or lint-free cloths to remove any grime. You can also use clean water and dish soap for stuck on bits of food or soap that won’t easily come off.

steps.headline: Clean mops in the dishwasher.
steps.description: Throw your mop head in the dishwasher along with other cleaning items like metal scrubbing brushes about once per month. You’ll kill germs by doing this and the cleaning process is a whole lot easier.

steps.headline: Do it before you plan on cleaning the inside of the dishwasher to reduce the overall germs in your home.
Change the rinse water regularly.
steps.description: To away the mop head getting stained it is important to replenish the water and add disinfectant.

steps.headline: Remove particles from the mob.
steps.description: Use a lint roller or your hands to pull away obstacles.

steps.headline: Store with the head up.
steps.description: This will help prevent mold and mildew.

steps.headline: Scrub away at the sink.
steps.description: Use a metal brush to get rid of food stains and soap deposits.

steps.headline: Bleach the sink.
steps.description: Drench paper towels with bleach and put around the sink.

steps.headline: Wash with lighter fluid.
steps.description: Lighter fluid will help remove rust and hard to get out stains.

steps.headline: Keep it free of clogs.
steps.description: Pour down baking soda, cream of tartar and salt down the drain every two weeks.

steps.headline: Use boiling water to clean the sink.
steps.description: Use boiling water to clean soap scum and other food residue in your sink. Sometimes the best thing you can do is simply to fill a tea kettle or large stockpot and let the water work its magic on your sink.

steps.headline: Check the bag is not full.
steps.description: Having a bag full of dust will cause your vacuum to lose suction.

steps.headline: Cut away threads in the roller.
steps.description: Tip your vacuum cleaner over and using scissors or your hands, carefully pull away fluff, hair and other debris.

steps.headline: Brush away obstacles.
steps.description: Check inside the pipes for any thing which may cause a blockage.

steps.headline: Clean vacuum cleaner with a wet cloth.
steps.description:
Disassemble your vacuum about once per month and clean it with a wet cloth. Your vacuum will work a whole lot better, and that in turn will make your entire house considerably cleaner.·        
Clean your attachments with wet paper towels too.

steps.headline: Put your sponge in the microwave.
steps.description: Dampen your sponge and put it in the center of the microwave on high for two minutes. It is good practice to do this everyday.

steps.headline: Boil the sponge.
steps.description: Place sponge in a pot of boiling water with a dash of bleach for five minutes.

steps.headline: Clean sponges in dishwasher.
steps.description: Disinfect sponges by putting them in the dishwasher every two weeks. You can dramatically prolong the life of your sponges and get rid of the stale smell and lingering germs.

text:
Cleaning Your Dishwasher Run an empty cycle. Every few weeks add bleach in the soap box or a cup of vinegar and run on the highest temperature. Clean dishwasher once a week. Clean your dishwasher by leaving it open to cool after you run it about once per week. That way all the steam can escape and it won’t build up on the racks in your dishwasher. Remove grime once a month. Wipe down the bottom section of your dishwasher about once per month with paper towels or lint-free cloths to remove any grime. You can also use clean water and dish soap for stuck on bits of food or soap that won’t easily come off. Cleaning Your Mops Clean mops in the dishwasher. Throw your mop head in the dishwasher along with other cleaning items like metal scrubbing brushes about once per month. You’ll kill germs by doing this and the cleaning process is a whole lot easier. Do it before you plan on cleaning the inside of the dishwasher to reduce the overall germs in your home.  Change the rinse water regularly. To away the mop head getting stained it is important to replenish the water and add disinfectant. Remove particles from the mob. Use a lint roller or your hands to pull away obstacles. Store with the head up. This will help prevent mold and mildew. Cleaning Your Sink Scrub away at the sink. Use a metal brush to get rid of food stains and soap deposits. Bleach the sink. Drench paper towels with bleach and put around the sink. Wash with lighter fluid. Lighter fluid will help remove rust and hard to get out stains. Keep it free of clogs. Pour down baking soda, cream of tartar and salt down the drain every two weeks. Use boiling water to clean the sink. Use boiling water to clean soap scum and other food residue in your sink. Sometimes the best thing you can do is simply to fill a tea kettle or large stockpot and let the water work its magic on your sink. Cleaning Your Vacuum Cleaner Check the bag is not full. Having a bag full of dust will cause your vacuum to lose suction. Cut away threads in the roller. Tip your vacuum cleaner over and using scissors or your hands, carefully pull away fluff, hair and other debris. Brush away obstacles. Check inside the pipes for any thing which may cause a blockage. Clean vacuum cleaner with a wet cloth. Disassemble your vacuum about once per month and clean it with a wet cloth. Your vacuum will work a whole lot better, and that in turn will make your entire house considerably cleaner.·        
Clean your attachments with wet paper towels too. Cleaning a Sponge Put your sponge in the microwave. Dampen your sponge and put it in the center of the microwave on high for two minutes. It is good practice to do this everyday. Boil the sponge. Place sponge in a pot of boiling water with a dash of bleach for five minutes. Clean sponges in dishwasher. Disinfect sponges by putting them in the dishwasher every two weeks. You can dramatically prolong the life of your sponges and get rid of the stale smell and lingering germs.
